thread.title: SCCS football wins over ranked Webb
thread.title_full: SCCS football wins over ranked Webb

author: Lorrie Reyes
title: SCCS football wins over ranked Webb
text:
SCCS football wins over ranked Webb Cardinals overcome early 14-point deficit to remain unbeaten in conference play Posted: October 18, 2015 12:22 a.m. Updated: October 18, 2015 12:22 a.m. SCCS' running back Seth Yu takes the ball to the goal line against Webb Schools at Canyon High on Saturday. Signal photo by Dan Watson. SCCS' defensive lineman Brandon Phillips (74) and Riley Perree (55) sack Webb Schools' quarterback Wyatt Albert in the first quarter at Canyon High on Saturday. Signal photo by Dan Watson. SCCS' Jacob Moss goes in for a touchdown against Webb Schools in the second quarter at Canyon High on Saturday. Signal photo by Dan Watson. 
Santa Clarita Christian’s Garrick Moss said the Cardinals’ 34-24 win over The Webb Schools of Claremont Saturday night at Canyon High was the biggest win in the history of the SCCS 11-man football program. 
But why was it the biggest win for SCCS? 
“One, because it’s against an incredibly well-coached team that beat us handily last year,” Moss explained. “Two, because it’s a league game, which is massive. And three, because they’re ranked in the top 10. We’ve never beaten a top 10 team as an 11-man school.”. 
Both SCCS and Webb came into Saturday night’s game with identical 5-1 overall records, as well as both hoisting a 1-0 San Joaquin conference record, but the Gauls are ranked No. 8 in the CIF-Southern Section East Valley Division. 
But it wasn’t only the biggest in SCCS 11-man history because of those reasons. 
The Cardinals had to overcome an early 14-0 deficit and SCCS quarterback Tristan Miller had to shake off three first-quarter interceptions. 
Webb’s Adrian Alvarez punched in the first score from 1-yard out and then Alvarez picked off Miller and returned it for a pick-6 late in the second quarter. 
But Miller, who went 26-for-40 with 255 yards, three touchdowns and four interceptions, settled down. 
Miller connected with Jacob Moss on the first play of the second quarter for an 8-yard TD and then Moss quickly turned around to pick off Webb’s Wyatt Albert to give his offense the ball back. 
Caden Brenner caught Miller’s second TD pass of the night, this time from 7-yards out on a slant pass. 
Then Moss, who had 146 receiving yards on 10 catches, caught his second touchdown of the night from Miller, a 28-yard pass play, to give the Cardinals their first lead (20-17) of the night with just two minutes left in the second quarter. 
SCCS wouldn’t let the lead slip away after that. That was mostly in part of the running game, and its defense. 
“We’re winning games because our defense is holding us in the games, and our offense is doing just enough,” said Moss, whose team moves to 6-1 and remains undefeated in Heritage League play (2-0). 
The running game was led by freshman Seth Yu who ran for 102 yards with a 55-yard touchdown up the left sideline to cap his night. 
At just 5 feet, 7 inches and 150 pounds, Yu was running in circles all night — mainly because his quick spin move was breaking tackles all over the field. 
“Seth’s last run was the play of the game. He ran hard all game,” Moss said. “For a kid that hasn’t got a start in a varsity game and for him to do that, is just a special moment.” 
But it was the Cardinal’s defense that kept SCCS’ offense on the field. 
SCCS was able to pick off Albert (7-for-17, 128 yards, 0 TDs) four times and forced three fumbles, including one recovery by Brenner where he nearly got in the end zone. 
Leading the Gauls Nick Jung with 114 receiving yards. Albert was able to punch in a rushing TD from 3-yards out. 
“I have a lot of respect for coach Moss and how they play,” said Webb head coach Amahl Thomas, whose team falls to 5-2 overall and 1-1 in league play. “I think if we play like this we’re going to do fine going forward. The meat of our schedule is still ahead of us, so if we can go and knock some of those teams off we’ll be alright.” 
The Cardinals next face Capistrano Valley Christian next Saturday at Canyon High.
